data.title: Stories of Faith, Grit and Joy
data.text:
When the burden of life became too heavy, Andrew Quach discovered God would carry him.

‚ÄúOne day I was walking through campus. It was just another day of trying to figure out what to do.‚Äù

Life pressed heavy on Andrew Quach that year. ‚ÄúI confined myself to this little space,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúI just went to school, went to practice, didn‚Äôt really let anyone in, locked myself in my room.‚Äù

Nearing the end of his sophomore year at George Fox, he had learned that his grandpa‚Äôs liver was functioning at less than 5%; he would have to go on dialysis. Quach grew up with his grandparents in his home. Caring for them was part of family life. This was a blow.

‚ÄúWe had other family members pass away because of kidney failure,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúIt was really heartbreaking for me to hear, especially because I wasn‚Äôt in California and I couldn‚Äôt be home to help take care of my grandparents and help my dad with the process.

‚ÄúAlong with that I was just in this head space of, ‚ÄòI don‚Äôt know what‚Äôs going on. Like, what am I doing?‚Äô I wasn‚Äôt doing well in academics, and I wasn‚Äôt performing as well as I wanted to in track. And it was like the world was just pushing me under the ground.‚Äù

What‚Äôs with All the Nice People?

College life didn‚Äôt start that way. Freshman year was a culture shock, but in a good way.

Originally from Los Angeles, Quach had planned to remain in California or head for the Boston area, hoping to be recruited for college basketball. Nothing had worked out yet by his junior year of high school, and his basketball coach mentioned a small Christian school in Oregon that might have a spot for him. But he knew nothing about George Fox ‚Äì or Oregon, for that matter. He stalled.

The summer after he graduated from high school, Quach visited. ‚ÄúThe campus was awesome,‚Äù he says, but there was more to the equation. He grew up minimally Buddhist. ‚ÄúI came in without a faith background, kind of oblivious to all that was going on. I had heard all the stereotypes of what a Christian is, so I was hesitant coming in.‚Äù But he came, and had to adjust to more than the rain.

‚ÄúEvery time I was on campus I would always get so many different, ‚ÄòHey, how are you doing?‚Äô from people I didn‚Äôt know,‚Äù he recalls. ‚ÄúAnd it was really staggering for me because I was like, ‚ÄòThese people are so nice. They genuinely want to get to know you, and they care.‚Äô‚Äù

This was something new. ‚ÄúWhen you‚Äôre in LA, you keep your head down. You don‚Äôt really talk to anyone. You mind your own business. Coming to Fox was such a big change. It was so significant.‚Äù

His first big freshman event, the ‚Äô80s Dance, came pretty close to touching bliss. ‚ÄúMy roommates and I dressed up in the worst ‚Äô80s outfits ever that we got from Goodwill. It was terrible; we spent $5 on it. EHS was packed to the brim with students I‚Äôve never met before. I didn‚Äôt even know that many people came to Fox. We were lifting people up, people were crowd surfing, and I took a moment to just look at it. I was like, ‚ÄòThis is awesome. This is amazing. I don‚Äôt think it could get any better than this.‚Äô‚Äù

As refreshing as this new community was, he didn‚Äôt know then how significant the care of strangers, and new friends, would be.

Not Alone Anymore

By his second year on campus, Quach had adjusted to the overt friendliness ‚Äì but not to his own unmet expectations in athletics and academics. Then he got that call from home. He knew his grandpa‚Äôs time was limited.

‚ÄúIt was really heartbreaking for me, and I struggled through that time,‚Äù he says. He felt every mile separating him from those he loved and what he had always known.

One evening after work, Quach called his best friends and asked them to go for a drive. The car was his safe space, but that night he needed more than silence. He needed people to listen to the thoughts and emotions he‚Äôd refused to voice. ‚ÄúI told them everything and they sat there and just listened,‚Äù he recalls. ‚ÄúThey prayed over me and helped me figure out the next steps I needed to do, and told me how they thought God could make a real difference in my life ‚Äì that I could put some of the weight on his shoulders and not go through this pain alone.‚Äù

Several hours later, Quach was headed to bed and decided it couldn‚Äôt get any worse, so why not try praying? ‚ÄúBefore bed I prayed, and I said, ‚ÄòHey God, I‚Äôve never tried this before. I don‚Äôt really know much about you, but I‚Äôd love to get to know you more and just want to take this first step.‚Äô

‚ÄúThe next day I was walking through campus and someone came up to me and was like, ‚ÄòHey, I don‚Äôt know you, you don‚Äôt know me, but I just feel like you are surrounded by the Holy Spirit and I just want to pray for you.‚Äô

‚ÄúThroughout the week a couple more people came up as well and they were just like, ‚ÄòHey, I feel like you‚Äôre struggling. I feel like God‚Äôs telling me you need help. Can we pray?‚Äô That entire week felt amazing. The weight came off my shoulders and I just thought, ‚ÄòWow, I‚Äôm not in this alone anymore.‚Äô‚Äù

That week, everything changed.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve been able to take that next step of having those genuine conversations that I‚Äôve wanted so much, and to experience the world the way it‚Äôs meant to be experienced,‚Äù says Quach, who graduated this spring with a degree in graphic design. ‚ÄúI‚Äôve learned that trusting in God in the hard times is not something you do after the fact. I didn‚Äôt have that relationship with God for the hardships I faced a while back. But now I feel so much more prepared.

‚ÄúI‚Äôve tried to strengthen my relationship with God in every single way possible. Just praying every night, reading through the Bible to strengthen my knowledge of Jesus and the sacrifice he made for us. I know now that I‚Äôm not alone, that he‚Äôs here with me.‚Äù

After four decades of waiting, it was Susan Marcu‚Äôs turn to walk across the stage.

‚ÄúThis has been a longing in my heart for my entire adult life,‚Äù says Susan Marcu (B22).

Marcu supported her husband through college in the ‚Äô80s and later her three children, including daughter Ashley, who graduated from George Fox in 2008.

Finally, 14 years later, it was her turn to walk across the stage. In December, Marcu earned a bachelor‚Äôs degree in psychology and mental health studies from the university‚Äôs Adult Degree Program.

Traditionally, George Fox legacy students are those who had a parent or grandparent attend the university. In the Marcu family‚Äôs case, that legacy is reversed, with Susan continuing the George Fox tradition that her daughter started.

Marcu attended college briefly right out of high school but never finished. ‚ÄúI was not ready,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúAnd it wasn't long after I forfeited that opportunity that I realized what I had forfeited.‚Äù

With three kids to raise, there was little time to fit in college classes. She pursued an entrepreneurial path instead as a seamstress and sewing instructor, later working full time at a CPA firm. Throughout her kids‚Äô childhood, Marcu encouraged creativity and found ways to grow her own skills.

‚ÄúMy art has always had a practical element to it,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúI taught sewing and art classes at my kids‚Äô school. Our house was a constant buzz of arts and crafts.‚Äù

As a creative maker and craftsperson throughout her life, she knew she wanted to use those gifts to help others. She began investigating art therapy programs and mapping out her plan. Earning a bachelor‚Äôs degree in psychology was the first step.

‚ÄúI really wanted to be at a Christian college, especially for psychology, which is primarily a secular area of study,‚Äù she says.

Marcu began taking courses in 2019, and because the university‚Äôs Adult Degree Program is all online, she was able to continue right through the COVID-19 pandemic.

‚ÄúI was doing this at a time when the world was upside down and all of our perceptions were on the line. Being in the coursework during the pandemic provided a unique opportunity to engage with my cohort and wrestle with the pressing issues we all faced,‚Äù she says.

In the end, all the hard work ‚Äì and the long wait ‚Äì ‚Äúwas 100% worth it.‚Äù

Since graduating, Marcu has been accepted into a master‚Äôs program for art therapy. Her heart is to work with kids who have experienced trauma, she says, but she is open to wherever the journey takes her. As someone who is ‚Äúalways in her element when doing art,‚Äù she wants to use her passion to help others ‚Äì and now she‚Äôs equipped to do just that.

‚ÄúI have grown exponentially through this program,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúIt‚Äôs broadened my point of view on so many things. I have been privileged to hear other perspectives and also get to know the people behind them. It has deepened my faith.‚Äù

Karisa‚Äôs art amplifies the voices of local refugees.

Karisa Keasey‚Äôs (G13) artistic gifts were born of pain. Her childhood was sometimes chaotic, and art was an escape. Trauma not only sparked her lifelong love for art, it also gave her a heart for the broken. Years later, as an art student at George Fox, Keasey wrestled with how to reconcile her creative talent with her desire for social justice. She could paint beautifully, but what good did that do?

Not long after graduating, Keasey ran across an article about the Syrian Civil War. She read about the horrific violence levied against innocent civilians, the barrel bombs and gas attacks, the refugees fleeing the devastation by the millions, leaving their beloved homeland behind in search of a better life in Europe or America. It broke her heart.

She decided to contact World Relief, a global Christian humanitarian organization that helps resettle refugees across the United States. Visiting World Relief‚Äôs Seattle office, Keasey learned more about the global refugee crisis and the needs of those resettled in the U.S. There, she realized that her artistic gifts could be uniquely useful.

‚ÄúRefugees are real people with real lives, not just statistics,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúWe needed a way of getting more of their stories to the public.‚Äù

Partnering with World Relief, Keasey met with refugee families in her community, visiting them in their homes to get to know them and hear their stories. Then, working from photos, she began to paint. The result was When You Can‚Äôt Go Home, a coffee table book that follows the lives of 10 refugees alongside 30 watercolor portraits.

The process took two years of coffees, teas, and countless conversations. She listened to tales of heartbreak and hope and spent endless hours capturing smiles and sorrow with paint and brush. There was the Rwandan who escaped genocide and made it to America, and the Eritrean man who crossed the Mediterranean with his wife, risking it all for the chance of a better life and nearly drowning along the way. When Keasey showed him the book, he teared up and thanked her: ‚ÄúSomeday I will get to share this with my kids so that they know what we fought for.‚Äù

‚ÄúI was very careful to portray them as people,‚Äù Keasey says. ‚ÄúA lot of times refugees are depicted in their worst moments. Those things happened, but we are all more than our worst moments. And so I tried to depict them not as victims but as victors ‚Äì not shiny and perfect, but with both the highs and the lows of their journey.‚Äù

Keasey‚Äôs goal is to spread awareness and amplify the voices of refugees in the Pacific Northwest, but she also wanted a more tangible impact. For every book she sells, Keasey gives 50 percent of the profits to World Relief, helping them continue their work of aiding and empowering refugees across the globe.

‚ÄúFor a long time, I felt like art was a useless gift,‚Äù Keasey says. ‚ÄúBut over the years God taught me that not only can each of our gifts be used to love others well, but they‚Äôre really central to his plan if we choose to say yes to him.‚Äù

Visit karisakeasey.com to learn more about Keasey‚Äôs book.

Nursing major Elysia Gonzalez is able to give others a voice ‚Äì because she found hers.

‚ÄúI never thought I would be able to go to college, because I didn‚Äôt finish high school.‚Äù

Elysia Gonzalez dropped out of high school when she was 16. Yet 10 years later, she was a nursing student at George Fox University, looking into the dark eyes of hundreds of young girls listening intently as she taught in schools on the slopes of Mt. Elgon in Kenya.

Education gives these girls the hope of changing their lives, of having a voice. Gonzalez, as she teaches and encourages them, is both the antithesis of this hope and the personification of it. She dropped out of school ‚Äì but she keeps learning and she sees how hard things helped create who she is today.

Invisible

Gonzalez knows what it‚Äôs like to blend into the edges, hoping to be invisible. She knows what it‚Äôs like to be lonely.

A Latina in a majority-white school in Keizer, Oregon, she was hard-working but quiet at school, with a frizzy cloud of hair and not enough money for the Miss Me jeans with the rhinestone pockets.

‚ÄúTeenagers get really caught up in who‚Äôs popular,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúI felt like I had a lot of problems when I was in high school. Not that I would get into trouble, but I didn‚Äôt have a lot of friends. Emotionally it was hard. Kids are so mean in high school. So I decided that it would be best if I got my GED and started working.‚Äù

Her 27-year-old self would tell her 16-year-old self to stick it out. And that‚Äôs precisely what she said to every Kenyan girl in every school that she and a group of George Fox nursing students visited ‚Äì with compassion, understanding how all-encompassing difficult situations are in the moment, but also with the conviction that comes with hindsight. As a junior in high school, she could not imagine tolerating one more year. And so she quit.

‚ÄúMy mom was really disappointed,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúMy mom went only to sixth grade. She understood how hard it was for me, but she really values education, so it was the hardest on her.‚Äù

Despite dropping out of high school, Gonzalez was not idle. Her parents raised her to work hard and save money, so she got her GED and began as a cashier at JCPenney. As soon as she turned 18, she took a job at Salem Health, handling patient registration. That‚Äôs when her own mom came in as a patient ‚Äì in a lot of pain, with unknown severity.

‚ÄúI was so worried, and that was one of the most horrible feelings I‚Äôve had, feeling like I didn‚Äôt understand what was going on, and feeling like I was helpless in the situation,‚Äù Gonzalez says. Her parents spoke English, but they didn‚Äôt know the medical world or health insurance. The family felt lost and scared.

‚ÄúThere was one day that I crawled into her hospital bed, and I was hugging her, and I told her, ‚ÄòOh Mom, I don‚Äôt want you to die.‚Äô‚Äù

Tears start immediately as Gonzalez remembers that day, years later. But while the doctor seemed brusque, the nurse assigned to them took a personal interest.

‚ÄúI felt like I could really trust her, leaving my mom there,‚Äù she says.

Gonzalez doesn‚Äôt even remember her name, but that nurse shaped her future. One year later, she entered Chemeketa Community College for her nursing prerequisites, and in 2022 transferred to George Fox as a sophomore nursing student.

‚ÄúI really like to be there for people who feel like they need it,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúThat personal interest she showed in my family and me ‚Äì even now, it has a really deep impact on us.‚Äù

Determined

Gonzalez remembers the frizzy hair, the loneliness, and the lost feeling as she teaches and plays with the Kenyan schoolgirls. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm grateful for going through that, because it made me a stronger person now,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúIt gave me some humility that I‚Äôm able to carry over now. I have an interest in people who are in the background. People like that go through a lot that they don‚Äôt voice, and you don‚Äôt know unless you get to know them. I would say the girls there are the strongest I‚Äôve ever met, with some of the things they‚Äôve had to deal with.‚Äù

Last year was not the first time George Fox nursing students visited Kenya, partnering with the Kenyan organization Marafiki, Swahili for ‚Äúfriends.‚Äù But it was the first time they focused on health education ‚Äì menstrual cycles, hygiene, the right to say ‚Äúno‚Äù ‚Äì rather than treating patients, trying to reach beyond immediate needs and shape this generation. Gonzalez found she has a gift for addressing hard topics and saying things people don‚Äôt want to hear.

‚ÄúI have an interest in people who are in the background. People like that go through a lot that they don‚Äôt voice, and you don‚Äôt know unless you get to know them.‚Äù

‚ÄúReflecting on things I was told when I was younger helps me to more carefully pick my words, especially where people may think they‚Äôre being personally attacked,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúI think, especially in healthcare, you have to have difficult conversations. The initial emotions behind that are not always accepting; sometimes it comes off as angry or confrontational. So you just have to have a calm demeanor, to pick your words carefully, to try and touch that person‚Äôs heart and get the message across that you need to.‚Äù

Gonzalez likes who she‚Äôs become. She was the only first-year nursing student accepted on the Kenya trip. She‚Äôs working at both Salem Health and Providence Newberg Hospital as a certified nurse assistant while studying to be a registered nurse.

Tucked inside the clear cover of her phone, she has a note from one of the schoolgirls. Invited to write anonymous questions to be answered by the nursing students, one girl wrote, ‚ÄúI want to be you.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt‚Äôs sad to think about someone wanting to be you, but whenever I feel like, ‚ÄòNursing school is so hard. How can I do this?‚Äô I remember I‚Äôm in such a fortunate position.‚Äù

Gonzalez will return to Kenya this summer. Whether there, or translating for a Spanish-speaking family in the emergency room, or calming a nervous patient awaiting a blood draw, she is determined to show people they are not invisible. They matter in a culture that may want them to blend into the edges. They have a voice.

Annika Pears overcame serious health setbacks to complete her degree.

Take it from Annika Pears, a graduate of the George Fox Adult Degree Program. In 2015, she was hospitalized with a severe stroke that changed the course of her life.

Pears was 11 weeks pregnant with her second child and living in Kansas, where her husband was stationed in the military. They were just months away from a dream they‚Äôd invested hours of time and most of their savings in ‚Äì opening a coffee shop together.

Then, in an instant, it was all wiped away.

‚ÄúI remember looking at the MRI and the entire left side of my brain was just completely black,‚Äù Pears recalls. ‚ÄúIt was just dead. I had to start from the very beginning. Our life literally took a 90 degree turn.‚Äù

It took weeks for her memory to start to come back. She had to relearn how to recall certain words, manage her emotions and navigate daily life. Eventually, stroke rehabilitation brought the Pears back to Oregon to be closer to family support. There were numerous appointments and therapies, not to mention a 3-year-old and a newborn to care for.

‚ÄúThe first time I said my ABCs, I was so slow. It was like pulling them from the very recesses of my brain,‚Äù Pears says. ‚ÄúMy emotional center was wiped out, so I was basically a 2-year-old in terms of my emotions. Once you realize what you‚Äôve lost, you can‚Äôt imagine that anything is going to get better. The stroke wiped the slate clean, but it also broke me down to this point where I had to build back up.‚Äù

An important step in her journey to healing came through helping others who had suffered a similar fate. When a friend‚Äôs mom had a stroke, Pears quickly offered to meet with her. Then, through another friend, she was connected with a pastor who had suffered two strokes and lost the ability to speak.

‚ÄúThere‚Äôs something about connecting with someone who‚Äôs on the other side of it,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúI know what it‚Äôs like to be trapped in your mind and how frustrating it is to not be able to get words out.

‚ÄúThrough these two scenarios, I realized, ‚ÄòWow, I have a story that can actually really help people. So why wouldn‚Äôt I?‚Äô‚Äù

As she began to come to terms with her stroke, Pears made an important promise to herself: to go back to school and get her bachelor‚Äôs degree.

‚ÄúYou realize that you don‚Äôt want anything to hold you back,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúI could either let this stroke completely stop me, or I could become the best version of myself. I decided my two daughters, my husband ‚Äì and really myself ‚Äì deserve nothing less than who I knew I was supposed to be. I knew I was supposed to finish my degree. Nothing was going to stop me.‚Äù

As a teenager, Pears hadn‚Äôt considered herself qualified to pursue college.

‚ÄúCollege was always something I really wanted to do, but like a lot of people I didn‚Äôt think I could do it,‚Äù she recalls. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt think I was smart enough. A lot of my friends were really smart, and I didn‚Äôt see myself that way. Now I know that‚Äôs a lie.

‚ÄúIt was a process to overcome these lies I‚Äôve been telling myself for years. They were embedded and entrenched. I think the stroke helped, because I had to rewire my brain.‚Äù

Part of stroke recovery is helping the brain make new connections to circumvent pathways that were damaged ‚Äì a process called neuroplasticity, or ‚Äúrewiring the brain.‚Äù A close friend encouraged Pears to see rehabilitation as a way to ‚Äúrewire her brain for God‚Äôs truth.‚Äù

‚ÄúIt doesn‚Äôt matter what anybody thinks. You‚Äôve got to do what God is asking you to do,‚Äù Pears says. ‚ÄúI don‚Äôt want my girls to think that anything can hold them back ‚Äì that they‚Äôre not good enough or smart enough. I want them to know that they can do it.‚Äù

In 2020, Pears enrolled in the Adult Degree Program to pursue a bachelor‚Äôs degree in social and behavioral studies. Like many adults who return to school, it was a daunting experience ‚Äì but for Pears, even more obstacles stood in her way.

‚ÄúI had no idea everything that 2020 would hold,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúLiterally, I was diagnosed with cancer, we opened a new business, and there was a pandemic. I also had two kids at home, so I was trying to figure out Zoom and homeschooling, too.‚Äù

For the next 16 months, Pears persevered through surgery, brain fog from radiation, schedule changes due to the pandemic, and the demands of parenting two kids with schools shut down ‚Äì all while completing presentations and assignments for her program.

‚ÄúThe Lord uses all of these things to continue to heal my mind ‚Äì to push me, even when I don‚Äôt want to push myself,‚Äù she says. ‚ÄúGetting my degree showed me that I was always worth it. God used George Fox to instill that belief in me.‚Äù

In April of 2021, despite all the obstacles, Pears graduated with her bachelor‚Äôs degree.

‚ÄúI want it to be a stake-in-the-ground moment for my girls,‚Äù she says, ‚Äúso they can look back and think, ‚ÄòMy mom finished her degree, and she did it when it was so hard. How can I let anything stop me?‚Äô‚Äù

Pears firmly believes that God guided her steps and brought her to this place for a reason. ‚ÄúI did this with the Lord. He led me, and I did it ‚Äì with a stroke brain, in the middle of a pandemic, with wildfires and an ice storm, while homeschooling two kids and helping launch our new coffee business.

‚ÄúI feel so much more capable now. Nothing can stop me from the places that I know the Lord wants to take me. It‚Äôs a belief that has taken root so deep inside ‚Äì I know that I‚Äôm capable of whatever I want to do next.‚Äù

A health scare and a tragic death in the family forced Anthony Pasion to lean on God.

‚ÄúBeing on the football team has been the best time of my life,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúJust being able to have guys that are brothers and going to be lifelong friends, that‚Äôs the biggest joy I‚Äôve had since being at Fox.‚Äù

Then, in an instant, football was taken away.

‚ÄúMy vision started going blurry, and I wasn‚Äôt really sure why,‚Äù Pasion says. ‚ÄúI ended up going into OHSU and they found out I had this thing called optic neuritis, which is inflammation of my optic nerves.‚Äù

The cause: an anti-MOG disorder in which the immune system mistakenly attacks healthy proteins in the eye. Pasion first felt the effects in his left eye at the end of his sophomore year, then as a junior in his right eye as well. More trips to see specialists and heavy doses of medication followed.

‚ÄúI was scared,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúI didn‚Äôt really know what to do, I didn‚Äôt know what was going on, and I didn‚Äôt know if my sight was ever going to come back.‚Äù

Worse yet, in the winter of 2020, at the peak of the COVID-19 pandemic, Pasion‚Äôs family felt the full force of the deadly virus, as his father, mother and sister all tested positive.

‚ÄúMy mom was in the hospital for two weeks, and then my dad was in the hospital for a month,‚Äù he says, reliving the horrific experience.

On Christmas day, his father passed away.

‚ÄúThat was the hardest thing I‚Äôve ever had to go through in my life,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúI‚Äôm still trying to deal with that every day. I was like, ‚ÄòWhy would God do this to me? Why would he take away my dad?‚Äô‚Äù

Even though he wasn‚Äôt playing, Pasion leaned on his teammates, coaches and George Fox family like never before.

Head coach Chris Casey checked in on him ‚Äúall the time.‚Äù So did defensive coordinator John Bates. And every week, like clockwork, there was a phone call or coffee visit with campus pastor Jamie Johnson. Then there were his ‚Äúbrothers‚Äù on the football team, who rallied around him with friendship and support when he needed it most. During this time, Pasion also palpably felt the impact his father had on his life.

‚ÄúEven though my dad wasn‚Äôt there in the present, I always felt him with me,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúEverything he taught me, I tried to carry on.‚Äù

He thought about what would make his father proud: to be a good student, to graduate, to be a good man. And as he slowly began to heal, so too did his relationship with God.

‚ÄúIt was hard to keep my faith at first,‚Äù he says, thinking back to the darkest times. ‚ÄúBut as the months went on, I felt my faith grow stronger.‚Äù

And after all that was taken away, something was returned: the ability to play football again. A new medication has subdued the optic neuritis, improving his vision and allowing Pasion to return to the field next semester for one last season before the fifth-year senior graduates in the winter of 2022.

‚ÄúSports is something that I‚Äôve loved my entire life,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúIf I wasn‚Äôt able to play football again, I‚Äôd be pretty devastated. Thank the Lord that he gave me my sight back!‚Äù

A business management major who may someday pursue a career in coaching or athletics administration, Pasion now looks to the future with a renewed sense of hope and a trust in God that can only be gained through trial by fire.

‚ÄúEach time I‚Äôve gone through something hard, I‚Äôve grown from it, I‚Äôve became stronger because of it,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúThe main thing that stands out to me from this experience is God is always going to be there. You may not realize it in the moment, and it may not feel like he‚Äôs always there, but he‚Äôs always going to be with you.‚Äù

A life-threatening heart defect as a child fuels Emery Miller‚Äôs desire to help others.

A word of advice for those who happen to meet Emery Miller: Don‚Äôt tell him he can‚Äôt accomplish something. You‚Äôre only fueling his fire and setting yourself up to be proven wrong.

Miller should have died before the age of 1. Born with a hole in his heart and a failing aortic valve, he required four open-heart surgeries before the age of 7. As a child, the hospital became a second home ‚Äì so much so that the facility offered his parents a reserved parking spot. He literally became the face of Phoenix Children‚Äôs Hospital, his smiling mug shot beaming on promotional posters encouraging people to support children like him.

All the while, Miller kept baffling his doctors. ‚ÄúBased on their tests, I should have been on the floor turning blue,‚Äù he says. ‚ÄúInstead, I was playing with toys. They said I was the happiest sick kid they‚Äôd ever seen.‚Äù

Doctors told him he would never play sports. He played T-ball. He was then told he would never play at the coach-pitch level. He did. Middle school ball? ‚ÄúOut of the question,‚Äù they said. He did that as well. Varsity baseball was the next test. Mission accomplished.

Today, Miller can‚Äôt help but chuckle when he ponders this reality: The kid who was told he would never be active ‚Äì never live a ‚Äúnormal life‚Äù ‚Äì is now playing collegiate baseball at George Fox University, overseeing a charity that‚Äôs operating in 13 states, and serving as a spokesperson for national organizations that include the American Heart Association and United Way.
